Award.AwardTitle: Topics in Nonparametric Statistics: Faster Minimax Rates, Large-p-Small-n Cross-Correlation Matrices, Survival Analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project focuses on three main statistical activities motivated by medical, engineering and insurance applications. The first one is the optimal denoising and decomposition of signals and images. Analysis of functional magnet resonance images (fMRI) in the human brain is a particular example of application. Loosely speaking, fMRI is a noisy time series of images which reflects the level of oxygen in blood during measurements. Because this is about dealing with oxygen in blood, the time series contains respiratory, cardiac and neural response to functional stimuli. The proposed statistical procedure will allow doctors and bioengineers to separate and denoise these components, with potential applications in developing new methods for diagnosis and treatment of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases. The second topic is the estimation of large cross-covariance/correlation matrices for noisy signals, with the number of elements in millions and sample sizes of just several hundreds. This is a familiar problem in statistical analysis of Chip-on-chip microarrays used to study bacteria. Another application is the study of neural plasticity, which is the ability of the brain to recognize neural pathways based on new experience and change in learning. This will allow physicians to create new methods for early diagnosis and treatment of stroke which is the 4th leading cause of death in the US. The third topic is adaptive and efficient estimation of hazard rate and survival function from indirect observations, including new methodology of sequentially controlled experiments and protocols. This research is motivated by new methods of radiation and drug therapy for lung and breast cancers as well as by innovative technologies of waste-water treatment and the actuarial problem of developing adaptive life tables.

The project focuses on three objectives. (1) Advance knowledge and understanding of nonparametric curve estimation to develop a general theory of shrinking local minimax estimation that allows statisticians to get a new benchmark for the quality of estimation and generate a family of more accurate estimators. Preliminary results indicate that new efficient estimators can be proposed either via mimicking oracles or via aggregation of different estimators in frequency domain. Most challenging and rewarding results are expected for multivariate curves where new rates can remedy the familiar curse of multidimensionality. Applications in statistical analysis of microarrays, fMRI, radiation and drug therapy of cancer cells, and innovative technologies of waste-water treatment are expected.(2) Develop new methods of inference for large cross-covariance/correlation matrices for noisy signals, based on wavelet methods and exponential inequalities that can be applied to dependent and non-Gaussian observations. The main application is the study of neural plasticity of the human brain. This allows doctors and bioengineers to observe changes in neural pathways based on new experience and change in learning with applications to treatment of stroke and other brain diseases.(3) Improve nonparametric theory and create efficient methods of hazard rate and survival function estimation for indirect observations, including a new methodology of sequentially controlled experiments and protocols.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has been focused on three main statistical activities motivated by medical, engineering and insurance applications. The corresponding project outcomes are as follows. The first major outcome  is the developed theory and methodology of optimal denoising and decomposition of signals and images. Analysis of functional magnet resonance images (fMRI) in the human brain is a particular example of application. Loosely speaking, fMRI is a noisy time series of images which reflects the level of oxygen in blood during measurements. Because we are dealing with oxygen in blood, the time series contains respiratory, cardiac and neural response to a functional stimuli. The developed statistical procedure, based on wavelet analysis, allows doctors and bioengineers to separate and denoise these components, with potential applications in developing new methods for diagnosis and treatment of Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases. The second major outcome  is the developed theory and methods of estimation of  large cross-covariance and cross-correlation matrices for noisy signals, with the number of elements in millions and sample sizes of just several hundreds. This is a familiar problem in statistical analysis of Chip-on-chip microarrays used to study bacteria. Another application is the study of neural plasticity, which is the ability of the brain to recognize neural pathways based on new experience and change in learning. The developed methodology  allows early diagnosis and treatment of stroke which is the 4th leading cause of death in the US. The third activity is adaptive and efficient estimation of hazard rate and survival function from indirect observations, including new methodology of sequentially controlled experiments and protocols. The developed methods have been used for analysis of relapses after breast cancer surgery  as well as for developing  innovative technologies of waste-water treatment and analysis of actuarial life tables.

     Among general contributions to the statistical theory, the main outcomes are: (i) The developed theory of shrinking local minimax which allows statisticians to get a new benchmark for the quality of estimation, and new efficient estimators are developed via mimicking oracles. (ii) New methods of inference for large cross-covariance/correlation matrices for noisy signals, based on wavelet methods and exponential inequalities. Results developed for large-p-small-n cross-correlation matrices can be applied to dependent and non-Gaussian observations. (iii) Nonparametric theory of efficient estimation of the distribution and probability densities of truncated and censored observations. For the first time in the literature, the effect of truncation and censoring is quantified via a proposed coefficient of difficulty, which allows appreciate  complexity of an underlying survival analysis. Further, sequential estimators are developed for the above-mentioned settings.

Broader impacts of the project  are defined by the joint research with: (a) The UTSouthwestern Medical School, Department of Molecular and Cell Biology at UTD and Moores Cancer Center at UCSD on statistical analysis of microarrays, fMRI, radiation and drug therapy of cancer cells, for finding efficient patient treatments for lung and breast cancers and brain diseases including stroke and Alzheimer's and Parkinson's Diseases. (b) Environmental company BIFAR on innovative technologies of waste-water treatment; (c) Actuaries of insurance company BCBS of Texas on nonparametric life tables. Six  graduate students, including three females, have participated in the research, and among them three defended PhD thesis. A new monograph ``Missing and Modified Data in Nonparametric Estimation" is published by Chapman&Hall, and research results have been disseminated through publications and publicly available R-software.
